Prisons that want to keep in touch with their gay communities are not being allowed to read these papers.
So we're going to be involved in a suit, probably,
that will do for a lot of the congressional correctional act in Kentucky,
and maybe one here at the Lompoc prison, and possibly one down in Texas as well.
And then the last thing that I want to talk about is the rights of gay students.
I went to several undergraduate schools.
I graduated from Michigan State University, which is where I first got involved in gay political causes.
And as a student, I brought a suit against the university for refusing to allow us to place a banner
on the two official posts, shall we say, of the university where you can announce events.
And Michigan State University is on the main thoroughfare.
40,000 cars a day pass through this intersection.
We wanted to put a banner that said, gay pride week, and the administration wouldn't let us.
So we filed an action against the university.
We didn't win, but it's probably because we weren't adequately prepared,
because we found out from some of our sources post-administration
that they had been warned by their lawyers not to do that again next year,
because they thought it would be some pretty serious trouble.
So the next year, we made an application to put up a banner and help without any problems.
Now this same school, sitting in a city that has an anti-discrimination ordinance,
which I helped lobby for in 1971, last year they allowed gay students to be kicked out of fraternities.
So even though you have an anti-discrimination ordinance,
it's not going to be worth a whole lot, and it's not enforced.
So there are continuing problems going on.
We found that there's a school in another school mission called Andrews College,
which is trying to kick out two students because they alleged they were gay.
There's a private college in Southern Chicago that once ran a bachelor's degree to a student
who's completed all his coursework and said this person is gay
and doesn't meet the good moral character requirements of our school,
and he can't handle this degree.
We find that the University of Arkansas in Batesville,
the school has granted official university recognition to the student organization there,
but they won't grant them any office space or any funding
or any of the benefits that might go along with official recognition.
There's two cases going on in Texas right now involving the rights of students
to get recognition at their campus,
and my last big gay rights case before I came to the West Coast
involved a lawsuit against Georgetown University in Washington, D.C.
because they would not grant recognition to the undergraduate
until the law school gave student organizations.
So there are still a lot of lawsuits involving students
as well as many other areas that are important.
We can become complacent during California.
It doesn't have a Sodom statue anymore.
We have a lot of protections.
People to a greater extent may be a lot more relaxed.
They're used to hearing about seeing a gay community.
It's sort of this old hat,
but in most parts of the country there's still a lot of problems,
and that's what national gay rights advocates is all about.
It's why they need to know that.
They're not doing this in the country.
Is U.S. advocates taking on any cases involving gay youth
and their rights to their sexuality if they have not been treated
as a concern?
Does that seem to be something in California that is sort of a issue?
And it's very complicated.
Yeah, there's a lot of problems in that area.
We have not taken on any cases
involving that issue.
I can't say we've been presented with any.
What we do in determining what cases to take is
we basically wait for people to come to us,
which is not much of a problem.
I get calls every day.
If a day doesn't go by, they don't get at least one call
saying they're concerned about some kind of discrimination
or adverse action.
But that particular issue hasn't reached us yet.
You do talk about this in housing.
I just want to point out that this city, Denver,
has a law that says two interrelated individuals
cannot live together.
And this is often used against gay couples.
It's the status of a person living in downtown.
We haven't had any complaints in a long time
about that kind of problem.
That is a way of certainly discriminating
against gay people without being so forthright.
It's the saying that we're not going to allow two gays
to live together.
The history of that kind of legislation,
I'm not so sure it was necessarily anti-gay,
but it was intended to keep noise down
and to protect sort of family-type environments.
But it certainly had an impact on gay people.
In some areas like that, it's very subtle
with the legislation.
In some states like Virginia, it's very vague.
